metadata.title: Advanced Week 2 — Monday (Day 1)
keyFeatures: Accessory work: RDL, Bulgarian split squat, leg press

structuredWorkout.title: Lower: Squat Emphasis
structuredWorkout.description: Primary squat day—heaviest volume of the week. Building on Week 1: if last week felt RPE 7, add 5-10lbs today; if it felt RPE 8.5, hold weight and focus on bar speed. Competition squat 5x5 @ RPE 7-8 (~70-75% 1RM), followed by pause squats to address weakness out of the hole, then accessories for quad/glute hypertrophy. Track: weight, reps, RPE per set, bar speed notes.

sections.title: Warm-Up
sections.overview: Prepare hips, ankles, and CNS for heavy squatting

exercises.name: Bike or Row

intensity.description: Light sweat, prepare muscles and joints

exercises.notes: Gradually elevate heart rate and body temperature

exercises.name: Leg Swings
exercises.notes: Forward/back and side-to-side — loosen hip flexors and adductors

exercises.name: Hip Circles
exercises.notes: Large circles clockwise and counter-clockwise — open up hip capsule

exercises.name: Ankle Mobility (Wall Drives)
exercises.notes: Drive knee toward wall while keeping heel down — critical for squat depth

exercises.name: Empty Bar Squats
exercises.notes: Focus on movement quality — depth, bar path, breathing pattern

exercises.name: Goblet Squats
exercises.notes: Light dumbbell or kettlebell — practice upright torso and depth

exercises.name: Competition Squat (High-Bar or Low-Bar)

intensity.description: Primary squat day — heaviest volume. If Week 1 felt RPE 7, add 5-10lbs. If RPE 8.5, hold weight and focus on speed.

exercises.tempo: 2-3 sec descent, no pause, explosive up
exercises.notes: Setup: Bar on traps (high-bar) or rear delts (low-bar), feet shoulder-width, toes slightly out. Execution: Big breath and brace, descend with control (bar path straight up/down), depth to parallel or below, drive up explosively. Focus: Maintain bracing throughout rep, no dive-bombing, speed off the bottom. If bar speed slows significantly on rep 4-5, you're too heavy—reduce next set. Record: weight, actual reps, RPE per set, bar speed notes (fast/moderate/slow).

sections.title: Secondary Variation
sections.overview: Pause squats to address weakness out of the hole

exercises.name: Pause Squat (2sec pause at parallel)

intensity.description: 60-65% 1RM — teaches patience and position maintenance

exercises.tempo: 2 sec descent, 2 sec pause, explosive up
exercises.notes: Setup: Same as competition squat. Execution: Descend to parallel, PAUSE for 2 full seconds (count 'one-thousand-one, one-thousand-two'), then drive up explosively. Don't relax in the hole—stay tight, maintain bracing, keep tension in quads/glutes. Purpose: Builds strength out of the hole, teaches positional awareness, reinforces proper depth. Common mistake: Relaxing during pause (losing tension leads to slower ascent).

sections.title: Accessories
sections.overview: Quad/glute hypertrophy and posterior chain work

exercises.name: Romanian Deadlift (RDL)

intensity.description: Hamstring/glute hypertrophy and posterior chain strength

exercises.notes: Execution: Hinge at hips (push hips back, not down), feel hamstring stretch as bar travels down shins to mid-shin, squeeze glutes to return. Keep knees slightly bent, don't round lower back. Focus on eccentric (feel the stretch) and glute contraction at top. Purpose: Hypertrophy for hamstrings/glutes, posterior chain balance.

exercises.name: Bulgarian Split Squat

intensity.description: Unilateral quad/glute work, addresses imbalances

exercises.notes: Setup: Rear foot elevated on bench (~12-18 inches), front foot 2-3 feet forward. Execution: Descend until front thigh is parallel (or below if mobile), drive through front heel to return. Front leg does all the work—rear leg is just for balance. Focus: Torso upright, knee tracks over toes (don't cave inward). Purpose: Addresses left/right strength imbalances, unilateral stability, quad/glute hypertrophy.

exercises.name: Leg Press

intensity.description: Quad volume without spinal load (recovery-friendly)

exercises.notes: Setup: Feet shoulder-width, mid-platform. Execution: Lower with control (full ROM, deep stretch but don't let lower back round), push through heels, full extension but don't lock knees aggressively (maintain slight bend at top). Purpose: Quad hypertrophy with minimal CNS demand—allows high volume without taxing recovery like more squatting would.

sections.title: Cooldown
sections.overview: Static stretching and light foam rolling

exercises.name: Quad Stretch
exercises.notes: Pull heel toward glutes, feel stretch in front of thigh

exercises.name: Hip Flexor Stretch
exercises.notes: Lunge position, drive hips forward, feel stretch in front of rear leg hip

exercises.name: Hamstring Stretch
exercises.notes: Seated or standing, reach for toes, feel stretch in back of thigh

exercises.name: Glute Stretch (Figure-4)
exercises.notes: Lie on back, cross ankle over opposite knee, pull knee toward chest

exercises.name: Foam Rolling (IT Band, Quads, Glutes)

intensity.description: Focus on sore/tight areas, don't overdo it

exercises.notes: Roll slowly over muscle bellies (not joints), pause on tender spots for 20-30sec

metadata.title: Advanced Week 2 — Tuesday (Day 2)
keyFeatures: Accessory work: Incline press, barbell rows, face pulls, triceps
Upper back emphasis for bench stability

structuredWorkout.title: Upper: Bench Emphasis
structuredWorkout.description: Primary bench day—heaviest pressing volume of the week. If Week 1 felt easy (RPE 7), add 5lbs today. Competition bench 5x5 @ RPE 7-8 (~70-75% 1RM), followed by close-grip bench for lockout/triceps strength, then upper back work (critical for bench stability) and arm accessories. Track all presses: weight, reps, RPE, bar path quality.

sections.title: Warm-Up
sections.overview: Prepare shoulders, chest, and upper back for pressing

exercises.name: Light Cardio

intensity.description: Walk, bike, or row — conversational pace

exercises.notes: Elevate heart rate, warm muscles and joints

exercises.name: Arm Circles
exercises.notes: Forward and backward—loosen shoulder joints, increase ROM

exercises.name: Band Pull-Aparts
exercises.notes: Activate rear delts and scapular retractors—essential for bench setup and shoulder health

exercises.name: Scapular Push-Ups
exercises.notes: In push-up position, protract (push shoulder blades apart) and retract (squeeze together)—teaches scapular control

exercises.name: Empty Bar Bench Press
exercises.notes: Practice setup: feet placement, arch, shoulder blade retraction, grip width, bar path

exercises.name: Competition Bench Press

intensity.description: Primary bench day — heaviest pressing volume. If Week 1 felt RPE 7, add 5lbs.

exercises.tempo: 2 sec descent, touch chest lightly, explosive press
exercises.notes: Setup: Feet flat on floor (or elevated if mobility limited), arch in upper back (not lower back), shoulder blades retracted and pinned to bench, grip width just outside shoulders (or wider/narrower based on preference). Execution: Unrack with assistance if heavy, position bar over sternum, big breath and hold, lower bar to chest (control descent 2sec, bar path slightly diagonal toward face), touch lightly (don't bounce), press explosively (drive through floor with feet, press bar up and slightly back toward rack). Breathe at top of each rep. Focus: Maintain arch and shoulder blade position throughout set, bar touches same spot on chest every rep (lower sternum), lockout fully but don't hyperextend elbows. Record: weight, reps, RPE per set, any bar path issues.

sections.title: Secondary Variation
sections.overview: Close-grip bench to address lockout/triceps weakness

exercises.name: Close-Grip Bench Press

intensity.description: 65-70% 1RM — lockout and triceps strength

exercises.notes: Setup: Same as competition bench but grip narrower—hands shoulder-width or slightly narrower (not too narrow, causes elbow stress). Execution: Lower to chest (same touch point as regular bench), keep elbows tucked closer to body (reduces pec involvement, emphasizes triceps), press explosively. Purpose: Builds lockout strength (top portion of bench), triceps mass and strength, teaches elbow position. Common mistake: Grip too narrow (stresses wrists/elbows), flaring elbows out (defeats purpose—keep them tucked).

sections.title: Accessories
sections.overview: Upper chest, upper back (critical for bench stability), triceps

exercises.name: Incline Dumbbell Press

intensity.description: Upper chest/front delt hypertrophy

exercises.notes: Setup: Incline bench 30-45°. Execution: Press dumbbells up and slightly together (don't bang them), control descent (feel stretch in upper chest), full ROM. Purpose: Upper chest hypertrophy, unilateral work (addresses imbalances), greater ROM than barbell.

exercises.name: Barbell Row (Pendlay or Bent-Over)

intensity.description: Upper back thickness — critical for bench stability and shoulder health

exercises.notes: Setup: Pendlay (row from floor each rep, torso parallel to floor) OR Bent-Over (hold position, torso ~45°). Execution: Pull bar to sternum (not belly button), squeeze shoulder blades together, control descent, no momentum (no body english). Purpose: Upper back strength and hypertrophy—strong upper back stabilizes bench press (provides shelf for bar, maintains shoulder position), prevents shoulder injuries. Pull volume should match or exceed pressing volume.

exercises.name: Face Pulls

intensity.description: Rear delt/upper back health — non-negotiable for powerlifters

exercises.notes: Setup: Rope attachment on cable, chest height. Execution: Pull rope toward face (not chest), externally rotate at end (thumbs point back toward ears), squeeze rear delts, control return. Purpose: Rear delt and upper back health, external rotation strength, shoulder injury prevention (balances all the pressing). Do these even when tired—shoulder health is non-negotiable.

exercises.name: Dumbbell Overhead Triceps Extension

intensity.description: Triceps hypertrophy (complements pressing)

exercises.notes: Setup: Seated or standing, single dumbbell held overhead with both hands. Execution: Lower dumbbell behind head (elbows stay pointing up, don't flare out), feel stretch in triceps, extend fully overhead. Control the eccentric (don't let dumbbell pull you down too fast). Purpose: Triceps hypertrophy, complements pressing (bigger triceps = stronger bench/lockout).

exercises.name: Chest Stretch (Doorway or Corner)
exercises.notes: Arm on doorframe or wall, lean forward, feel stretch in chest and front shoulder

exercises.name: Shoulder Stretch (Cross-Body)
exercises.notes: Pull arm across body, feel stretch in rear shoulder

exercises.name: Triceps Stretch (Overhead)
exercises.notes: Reach arm overhead, bend elbow (hand behind head), pull elbow with other hand

exercises.name: Band External Rotations

intensity.description: Shoulder health maintenance

exercises.notes: Elbow at side, 90° bend, rotate hand away from body using light band — strengthens rotator cuff

metadata.title: Advanced Week 2 — Thursday (Day 4)
keyFeatures: Secondary squat work: Front squat 3x6 (lighter than Monday)
Posterior chain accessories: GHR, leg curls

structuredWorkout.title: Lower: Deadlift Emphasis
structuredWorkout.focus: Competition Deadlift + Secondary Squat + Posterior Chain
structuredWorkout.description: Primary deadlift day—most taxing lift of the week. Competition deadlift 5x4 @ RPE 7-8 (~70-75% 1RM), followed by deficit deadlifts for off-the-floor strength, then front squats (secondary squat work, lighter than Monday) to maintain squat frequency, finishing with posterior chain accessories. Don't grind reps—if bar speed slows significantly, stop the set. Track: weight, reps, RPE, bar speed, any form breakdown.

sections.title: Warm-Up
sections.overview: Prepare posterior chain, hips, and spine for deadlifting

exercises.name: Light Cardio

intensity.description: Walk, bike, or row — warm muscles

exercises.notes: Gradually elevate heart rate, warm posterior chain

exercises.name: Leg Swings
exercises.notes: Forward/back and side-to-side—loosen hips and hamstrings

exercises.name: Hip Openers (90/90 Stretch)
exercises.notes: Sit with both legs at 90°, lean forward over front leg—opens up hip capsule

exercises.name: Cat-Cow
exercises.notes: Hands and knees, arch and round spine slowly—mobilizes thoracic and lumbar spine

exercises.name: Empty Bar RDLs
exercises.notes: Practice hip hinge pattern—push hips back, feel hamstring stretch, neutral spine

exercises.name: Light Deadlifts (Build-Up Sets)

intensity.description: Bar, 135, 185, 225, etc. — work up to working weight

exercises.notes: Focus on setup perfection: feet position, grip, chest up, lats engaged, bracing

exercises.name: Competition Deadlift (Conventional or Sumo)

intensity.description: Primary deadlift day — most taxing lift. Don't grind reps; if bar speed slows significantly, stop set.

exercises.tempo: Controlled setup, explosive pull, controlled descent
exercises.notes: Setup (CRITICAL): Feet hip-width (conventional) or wide (sumo), bar over mid-foot, shins vertical, grip just outside legs (double-overhand or mixed grip—save straps for 80%+ loads), chest up (not chest down), lats engaged (imagine 'bending the bar' around your shins—pull slack out of bar, you should feel tension before pulling), big breath and brace (360° brace—belly, sides, lower back). Execution: Push floor away with legs (don't yank bar with back), bar scrapes shins and thighs (stays in contact with body entire lift—if bar drifts forward you lose leverage), hips and shoulders rise together (don't shoot hips up first—turns deadlift into stiff-leg and strains back), lockout with glutes (stand tall, squeeze glutes, don't lean back excessively or hitch). Lower with control (don't drop aggressively—controlled descent prevents injury). Focus: Perfect setup every single rep, bar speed (if rep takes >4-5sec or you feel back starting to round, stop set), breathing and bracing between reps. Record: weight, reps, RPE per set, bar speed notes, any form issues (hips shot up? back rounded? bar drifted forward?).

exercises.name: Deficit Deadlift (1-2 inch platform)

intensity.description: 60-65% 1RM — builds off-the-floor strength, increases ROM

exercises.notes: Setup: Stand on 1-2 inch platform or plates (standard is 1-2 45lb plates stacked). Same setup as competition deadlift but starting position is lower (bar starts lower, more knee bend required). Execution: Same cues as competition deadlift—push floor away, bar stays close, hips/shoulders rise together. Purpose: Strengthens off-the-floor position (where most people are weakest), increases ROM (builds strength through greater range), reinforces proper setup (can't cheat by setting up high). Common mistake: Too much height (>2 inches compromises form—stick to 1-2 inches).

sections.title: Secondary Lift
sections.overview: Front squat — secondary squat work to maintain frequency

exercises.name: Front Squat OR High-Bar Squat

intensity.description: 60-65% of back squat 1RM — lighter than Monday but maintains squat frequency

exercises.notes: Purpose: Maintains squat frequency (competition lifts practiced 2-3x per week for skill retention), lighter than Monday's primary squat day, quad emphasis. Front squat: Bar rests on front delts (elbows high, chest up), teaches upright torso and quad strength. High-bar squat: If you already do low-bar on Monday, high-bar here provides variation while maintaining pattern. Focus: Speed and depth, not load—this is lighter work to maintain movement pattern and build volume.

exercises.name: Glute-Ham Raise OR Nordic Curls

intensity.description: Posterior chain hypertrophy (hamstrings/glutes)

exercises.notes: Execution: Control eccentric (slow descent), use hands to assist on concentric if needed (pushing off floor with hands to return to start). Purpose: Hamstring and glute hypertrophy, eccentric strength (injury prevention—strong hamstrings protect knees). Very challenging—don't worry if you need assistance on the way up.

exercises.name: Leg Curls (Lying or Seated)

intensity.description: Hamstring isolation, complements compound work

exercises.notes: Execution: Curl weight up (squeeze hamstrings at contraction), control descent (don't let weight drop). Purpose: Hamstring isolation and hypertrophy, complements deadlifts and GHRs, easier to recover from than more deadlifting.

exercises.name: Hamstring Stretch
exercises.notes: Seated or standing, reach for toes, feel stretch in back of thigh

exercises.name: Glute Stretch (Figure-4 or Pigeon)
exercises.notes: Lie on back (figure-4) or pigeon pose, feel stretch in glute and hip

exercises.name: Lower Back Stretch (Child's Pose)
exercises.notes: Kneel, sit back on heels, extend arms forward, relax lower back—gentle stretch after heavy deadlifts

exercises.name: Cat-Cow
exercises.notes: Gentle spinal mobility after deadlifts—arch and round slowly

exercises.name: Light Walking

intensity.description: Flush blood through legs, reduce stiffness

exercises.notes: Slow pace, just for movement and recovery
